Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They encounter choices where Christian ethics become more relevant
Story:
I stared at the notice tacked to the break room wall: “Optional Safety Training—Next Wednesday, 6:00–8:00 PM.” The foreman said it’d look good if we all showed up, even though it wasn’t required. I knew the team expected me to be there, to show I was committed and reliable. But Wednesday nights were when I led Bible study at church. It wasn’t just a routine for me—it was a chance to encourage others, to live out my faith, and to keep myself grounded in what I believe is right. 

I could already hear the guys joking if I skipped the training, maybe even doubting my dedication to the crew. But if I missed Bible study, I’d feel like I was letting down my church family and, more importantly, compromising my values. The pressure built inside me, tugging me in two directions. I wanted to be a good worker, a dependable teammate, but I also wanted to stay true to my faith. I sat there, torn, the notice fluttering slightly in the draft, and wondered how I could possibly choose.
